text: hi everyone ruffne Palm Tano here the
internet's busiest music nerd and it's
time for a review of this new annoni and
the Johnson's record my back was a
bridge for you to cross this is the
latest full-length LP from vocalist and
songwriter Anoni higarti as well as her
band the Johnsons which comes about six
years after debuting under her new name
on the record hopelessness which was far
from my favorite record from her but was
a very challenging and emotionally
intense listen nonetheless a devastating
Art Pop record that truly wept for the
world especially on Highlights such as
Jerome bomb me so considering this
public shift in identity and topical
Focus it's understandable that Anoni
would want to move away from the band
she was once known for leading but with
my back was a bridge for you to cross
the band is back and so is agarti's
focus on chamber pop and especially
Seoul but at least some of the social
commentary has remained I don't think
you put LG gbtq activist Marsha P
Johnson on the front cover of your
record if you're not looking to make
some kind of point it's also worth
noting how much of a full circle moment
this is as the and the Johnson's band
name has always been in reference to
Marsha her life and work if you've been
paying attention to the news you've most
likely seen it's currently dire times
for the queer Community with a lot of
public vitriol state and local
legislation getting passed as well as a
right-wing Supreme Court stacked against
it and a Noni seems more than the game
to address that and a host of other
things on this record but does it in
kind of a poised classy Timeless
unshaken way that reminds me of Records
such as Marvin Gaye's what's going on
most notably on the opening track it
must change without having to be too
explicit the it in that sentence is
pretty obvious but hegarti does go the
extra mile through spell things out with
some poetic Grace the way you talk to me
the things you do to me the death inside
you that you pass into me the backing
instrumental as well of warm bass and
clean guitar some hand drums too is so
smooth and so sweet it's fantastic but
also meets the moment emotionally as
well continuing through the track list
there is an interesting contrast on the
next song which is the shortest and
harshest on the project go ahead the
shrill guitars and shouty vocals sound
like a total racket off of a late era
Scott Walker album lyrically hegarti
seems to take on the vitriol and hatred
being sung about on the track again it's
short it's not super well developed or
thorough or anything like that but I
think the pieces Point gets crossed
pretty easily sliver of ice deals in
Vibes and emotions that are much more
positive and nourishing mostly love with
some very slow and enchanting drums and
guitars hanging in the background a
noni's voice on this cut is amazing
especially that low end the lyrics
deliver this imagery of of bliss related
to The Taste of water and ice which in a
way is like in two love or something new
my and expanding but the track is still
Bittersweet as there's a lot of talk of
passing on and not being around for too
much longer entering into some kind of
unexplained Oblivion all in all it's a
pretty somber and beautiful moment on
the project we get much more emotional
tension on the following can't which
reads like an Ode to a friend who's
passed on and possibly another where
some distance has grown between hegarti
and them due to some regrettable actions
or other factors the specifics come
across a little open to interpretation
but the sadness and longing is most
definitely there as well as the
momentous Crescendo the whole thing
arrives to toward the Finish shouting in
protest I won't have it can't undo it I
don't want you to be dead the social
points on this record are made even
clearer with the song scapegoat with
opening lyrics like you're so killable
just so killable it's not personal it's
just the way you were born and in this
Society a scapegoat is all I can be
there are sight expansions on this track
lyrically as it continues to unfold but
the real uh I think selling point of
this song is the vocal performance not
only is the passion there but the vocal
Melodies are super angular and unique
and there's this really intense vibrato
that is fluctuating so much in volume I
can't think of a lot of examples that
remind me of it moving on from here
there's a pretty decent second half on
the record too the track it's my fault
given its length kind of reads like a
bit of a mid-album breather not my
favorite tune here but there are some
beautiful Harmony layers on the chorus
and the lyrics read like an interesting
meditation on internalizing blame there
are similar struggles of not Measuring
Up explored as well on the song there
wasn't enough the track rest is a pretty
direct and heavy Fusion of Rock and Soul
with some mesmerizing guitar arpeggios
and the strongest and most dramatic
combination of instrumentation and
vocals on the entire record this track
is handily the most fiery here
especially with that peak in the last
leg the Dynamics of this album not just
in terms of performance but the
recording as well how much it
complements uh the softer moments the
louder moments it's all great the record
does end off with some kind of loose
moments like with why am I alive now
which just refuses to resolve as far as
chord progression and The Melodies are a
bit uh on edge too even when a really
sweet and cinematic string section
begins to pick up in the last leg but I
will say hegarti does lace another
impressive vocal performance into this
track even if again I'm not blown away
by the song or tune itself but then the
closing cut which is a very skeletal and
simple short moment on the record you be
free is a bit of a guitar meditation
that again is very bare and very
straightforward but I think delivers a
vital message one that is of Hope and I
think relates to not just uh Johnson on
the cover but also higarti herself who
has long stood as a queer figure in the
public in the art scene and the whole
thing reads like a statement on
generations of people struggling in
order for those who come after them to
see brighter days and hopefully
experience less cumbersome existence and
yeah overall loved this album I think it
is one of these stronger records that a
note me has released over the course of
her career and feeling a strong a20
light nine on this one transition have
